top_ideas.description: In patriarchal society, woman is not defined as a subject in her own right but as 'the Other' in relation to man. This foundational idea critiques the structural othering of women and calls for existential liberation.

De Beauvoir combined existentialist ethics with feminist analysis, asserting that women must create their own essence through free action and transcend the roles imposed upon them by culture and history.

top_ideas.idea: One Is Not Born, but Rather Becomes, a Woman
top_ideas.description: Gender is not innate but socially constructed. This revolutionary idea challenged essentialist views of womanhood and became foundational for feminist theory, especially gender performativity.
Human freedom exists in tension with ambiguity. We are free, but our choices are constrained by our facticity (social, historical, physical conditions). Ethics must navigate this tension.

Women have been relegated to 'immanence'—the passive, interior, and repetitive—while men claim 'transcendence'—activity, progress, and external creation. Liberation requires women reclaim transcendence.
Building on Hegel and Sartre, de Beauvoir emphasized that authentic human relations require reciprocal recognition of freedom. Domination—especially gendered domination—destroys this reciprocity.
De Beauvoir argued that genuine ethics must be rooted in freedom, responsibility, and the active promotion of others’ freedom. Oppression is unethical because it denies others their subjectivity.

top_ideas.idea: Old Age as a Social and Existential Problem
top_ideas.description: She explored how aging strips individuals of subjectivity in the eyes of society, mirroring how women are objectified. She examined the marginalization and invisibility of the elderly.
The idea that there is an essential 'feminine nature' is a myth constructed by patriarchal culture. This myth freezes women into predefined roles, denying them historical and existential freedom.

top_ideas.idea: Intersection of Existentialism and Social Structures
top_ideas.description: Though existentialism emphasizes personal freedom, de Beauvoir insisted on the material and social limits imposed on individuals—particularly women—and challenged pure voluntarism in favor of historical consciousness.
De Beauvoir saw literature as a powerful means to explore ethical and existential dilemmas. Through fiction and memoir, she enacted the complexity of moral freedom and responsibility.
